titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cora Williamson ephemera collection 1985.030
titlestmt.author: John Zarrillo

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-31 14:45:10 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The collection consists of three items of 19th century ephemera belonging to a schoolgirl named Cora Williamson.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Immediate source of acquistion is unknown. Collection accessioned in 1985.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Cora Williamson (1867?-1932) was a lifetime resident of Brooklyn Heights, where she resided at 44 Livingston Street. She was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S.H. Williamson, had two sisters, Louise and Lilly, and one brother, Alfred. She died in her home in 1932 and is buried in Green-Wood Cemetery.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Cora Williamson ephemera collection, 1985.030, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 19th century ephemera belonging to a schoolgirl named Cora Williamson. It contains a printed card with a poem titled "The Little Nurse;" one Reward of Merit certificate to Williamson from Rosa J. Prall, teacher; and one envelope addressed to Williamson at 44 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain.
